questions.question_text:
Your web application requires logic to remember items that a user placed into a shopping cart.
Which two mechanisms should you use to associate that information with the user? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Answer B, C. ServletResponse not useful. Database not needed.
I think answers are BC, because a data base is not in the Web App as a resource.
The answers should be C (HttpSession objects) and D (a database).

choices.D: No method will be invoked and a 404 error will be returned.
choices.C: No method will be invoked and no error will be returned.
choices.A: The findAll() method will be called and the employee list will be returned.
choices.B: The findAll() method will be called and no employees will be returned.

discussion.content: Answer B. HEAD by default invokes the implemented GET method (if present) and ignores the response entity (if set). This method can be used for obtaining metadata about the entity implied by the request without transferring the entity-body itself.

questions.question_text:
You are building the User Preferences page of an application. A user can change values, such as his or her name, password, address, company, and so on.
These values are sent to a CDI backing bean via AJAX when the user tabs out of each field. However, the values must be retained in the CDI bean and stored in the database only when the user clicks the Save button.
Which two scopes will allow your CDI bean to retain its state while the user is interacting with the User Preferences page? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Answer B, C. Application Scope and Dependent Scope surely not. Request Scope only retains data by the duration of a request. View and Session scope is correct.
Answer should be : B and C
according to this https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/cdi-basic008.htm, C and E are correct
The answer should be B and C (View and Session).

D is the correct asnwer.
JSR 338 JPA 2.1 page 95 of the specification:
When an application locks an entity with LockModeType.PESSIMISTIC_READ and later updates that entity, the lock must be converted to an exclusive lock when the entity is flushed to the database[42].

Answer D. 
LockModeType.READ Synonymous with OPTIMISTIC.

PESSIMISTIC_READ - locks the record with read lock state when you read the record. This prevents other transactions from changing the record, but still allows them to read it.

PESSIMISTIC_WRITE - locks the record, preventing other transaction from reading and writing it.

choices.B: This operation will force serialization among transactions attempting to read the entity data.
choices.A: LockModeType.PESSIMISTIC_READ is the synonym of LockModeType.READ
choices.C: This operation will result in a TransactionRolledbackException if the lock cannot be obtained.
choices.D: If the application updates the entity later, and the changes are flushed to the database, the lock will be converted to an exclusive look.

questions.question_text: A Persistence application locks entity x with a LockModeType.PESSIMISTIC_READ lock type. Which statement is true?

choices.B: Method parameters and return types must be JAXB compatible.
choices.C: Method parameters must be declared by using @WebParam.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about Java methods that are exposed as Web Service operations by using JAX-WS API?

discussion.content:
Answer B. the question don t mention if is a session bean so D is not correct.
JAX-WS requirements:
-Must be public. By default every public method in the class will be part of the webservice.
- Must not be static of final
- Must have JAXB-compatible parameters and return types. Parameters and return types must not implement the java.rmi.Remote interface.
- Business methods (Session Bean) that are exposed to web service client must be annotated with javax.jws.Webmethod
D is correct according to (Requirements of a JAX-WS Endpoint) : https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E17802_01/webservices/webservices/docs/2.0/tutorial/doc/JAXWS3.html
